definition: lit. to crawl like a snail and plod along like an old ox (idiom)/fig. to move at a snail's pace/to make slow progress
snail/Taiwan pr. [gua1]/see 蝸牛|蜗牛[wo1 niu2]

to walk/to go/to travel/a visit/temporary/makeshift/current/in circulation/to do/to perform/capable/competent/effective/all right/OK!/will do/behavior/conduct/Taiwan pr. [xing4] for the behavior-conduct sense
row/line/commercial firm/line of business/profession/to rank (first, second etc) among one's siblings (by age)/(in data tables) row/(Tw) column
surname Niu
ox/cow/bull/CL:條|条[tiao2],頭|头[tou2]/newton (abbr. for 牛頓|牛顿[niu2 dun4])/(slang) awesome
surname Bu
a step/a pace/walk/march/stages in a process/situation
lit. old ox pulling a shabby cart (idiom)/fig. slow and inefficient
see 老牛破車|老牛破车[lao3 niu2 po4 che1]
to go on foot (idiom)/to do things at a leisurely pace
(self-deprecating) to have grown old without accomplishing anything (idiom)
an old horse knows the way (idiom); an experienced worker knows what to do/an old hand knows the ropes
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
to walk quickly/striding quickly
very slow
clay ox, wooden horse (idiom); shape without substance/worthless object
lit. the sun setting and the moon rising (idiom)/fig. the passage of time
proceeding at a tremendous pace/getting on like a house on fire
a thousand tries leads to one success (idiom, humble expr.); Even without any notable ability on my part, I may still get it right sometimes by good luck.
the sun and moon like a shuttle (idiom); How time flies!
lit. stout horses and light furs/fig. to live in luxury
see 亦步亦趨|亦步亦趋[yi4 bu4 yi4 qu1]
